results.title: Home to the sea
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television and Boris Holtzman
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Examines rights of passage, fishing and mineral concessions, and the kinds of ecological safeguards needed to assure that the natural resources of the sea will be protected from exploitation by selfish national interests.

results.title: Home sweet home
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Suzanne Baker and Philip Robertson
results.brief_description: Shows the organisation and effort required to reconstruct Darwin after it had been destroyed by Cyclone Tracy on Christmas Day, 1974. Illustrates the social impact of the cyclone.

results.title: Home safe home
results.creator_credit: Macko Productions, Charles Cahill and Associates and Charles Cahill
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Safety”.
Shows basic concepts of home safety to elementary students. Major areas covered include: fire, electricity, poisons, slip and falls, cuts and bruises.

results.title: Home of the Kodavas
results.creator_credit: Documentary Films of India, M. Bhavnani and A. Bhaskar Rao
results.brief_description: Life in the little known state of Coorg in South India. The martial Kodavas, their quaint customs and simple pleasures. Coorg, nestling in a chain of hills, abounds in fertile fields and luxuriant jungles. A land of streams and rivers, including Kaveri the sacred river of the south.

results.title: Home of the homeless
results.creator_credit: United Nations. Dept. of Public Information and Arthur Zegart
results.brief_description: A story of life in an IRO Displaced Persons’ Camp in Germany. Housed in an old Nazi army barrack, the people live from day to day, always hoping that some country will accept them as immigrants. The film captures the austere living conditions in the camp and the frustration and lonliness of the people. In spite of frequent disappointments, most people have not given up hope of finding a home and useful work. Narrated by Henry Fonda.

results.title: Home of the brave (1986)
results.creator_credit: Talk Normal Productions, Paula Mazur and Laurie Anderson
results.brief_description: Neither a feature film or documentary, “Home of the brave” is a concert film, essentially a record of Laurie Anderson’s “Mister Heartbreak” tour of 1986. Joined by some exemplary performers, Anderson’s legendary show combines computer synthesized music, video, slides and provocative monologues. Having an international reputation since the 1970’s for her use of cutting edge technology in her avant garde performances and music, Anderson is on show with some of her most well-known and energised works to date. Featuring William S. Burroughs as himself with his introduction to Sharkey’s Night, Won-Sang and Sang-Won Park delivering dialogue accompanied with traditional Japanese instrument, the kayageum, “Home of the brave” presents a poetic collaboration of Western and Asian aesthetics with ‘attitude’. Other musicians include: Joy Askew, Adrian Belew, David Van Tieghem, Richard Landay, Richard Landry IV, Dolette McDonald and Janice Pendarvis.

results.title: Home of the brave
results.creator_credit: Edward Street Films, Victoria. Disability Services Division, Film Victoria, Katherine Scholes and Roger Scholes
results.brief_description: Provides an historical overview of the evolution of models for the care of the intellectually disabled; from the institutions of the early 1800’s through to current the community living options. The strength of the institutions is acknowledged but the real restrictions on quality of life are highlighted. Examines issues surrounding people with an intellectual disability moving from institutions into the community, especially the nature and extent of support services. Accompanied by a 3p. Study Guide inside the cover.

results.title: Home of the blizzard (1913)
results.brief_description: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. An artist interested less in expressing human experiences than the grandeur of nature and the romance of exotic lands, his work was known to Australians through books, newspaper features and documentary films.
results.description: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. An artist interested less in expressing human experiences than the grandeur of nature and the romance of exotic lands, his work was known to Australians through books, newspaper features and documentary films. His journeys began in December, 1911 when he joined Mawson’s expedition to Antarctica as official photographer; his stills of the Expedition were widely published around the world and this documentary “Home of the Blizzard” was released in 1913.
description_for_label: Frank Hurley (1885-1962) was firmly established by 1925 as Australia’s most famous photographer. An artist interested less in expressing human experiences than the grandeur of nature and the romance of exotic lands, his work was known to Australians through books, newspaper features and documentary films. His journeys began in December, 1911 when he joined Mawson’s expedition to Antarctica as official photographer; his stills of the Expedition were widely published around the world and this documentary “Home of the Blizzard” was released in 1913.

results.title: Home nursing
results.brief_description: Bathing the patient and moving them in bed; arranging the bed; making the patient as comfortable as possible; taking and recording pulse, temperature, and respiration; preparing both patient and patient’s room for the doctor’s visit.
